Facebook is commissioning an independent study on "the effects of social media on elections and democracy," CEO and co-founder Mark Zuckerberg announced on Monday.
This is a new model of collaboration between researchers and companies, and it's part of our commitment to protect the integrity of elections around the world," Zuckerberg wrote on Monday.
The foundations will select the academic experts who will serve on the committee in the coming weeks, Facebook said in a press release.
"Looking back, it's clear we were too slow identifying election interference in 2016, and we need to do better in future elections.
Facebook said it won't be given the right to review or approve the experts' findings prior to the publication of their research.
Instead, the "focus will be entirely forward looking" at upcoming elections in Brazil, India, Mexico and the U.S. midterms.
Zuckerberg has acknowledged that he made a "huge mistake" by not paying closer attention to potential data abuse in 2016.
"It is urgent that we find solutions that are based on sound analysis, which we cannot do without access to data.
"I'm not going to sit here and say that we're not going to find more, because we are," Sandberg said.
